The Blue Ribbon Panel's final
report on undergraduate
education has met high praise
and satisfaction among members
of the Academic Council. The
AC will begin in depth discussion
on specific BRP recommendations this week.
President Muller characterized
the report as "good and useful,"
but cautioned that it might be
some weeks before the AC could
take definite action due to shifts
in Arts and Sciences
administrative posts.
Many Council members
expressed pleasure with the
report's unexpected emphasis on
undergraduate non-academic life,
and the recommendation that a
Dean of Students be appointed
to tackle such problems directly.
Muller said he personally
favors such a post, preferably by
someone of faculty stature. "I
don't think we can do justice to
undergrads without such a post,"
he added.

President Muller's administrative re-shuffling should
bring a welcome cohesion to an often fragmented
bureaucracy. Muller appointed Dean George Benton to
the new post of Vice President for Homewood and
Benjamin Willis, Vice President for Administration, to
the newly created job of Director of the Budget.
Hopefully, this will improve the key management
functions of budget planning and of overseeing several
of Homewood's non-academic areas. The vaguely
defined responsibilities of the Provost's office and the
Administration Vice-Presidents will be clarified with
the focus provided by these new posts. The new
Homewood dean will be better able to devote his
attention to strengthening and broadening the
academic program. but a major opportunity will have
been lost if the University fails to meet the crisis of
campus life.
Unless the new dean is supplemented by a strong
Dean of Students, even the attention Benton promises
to give to such matters as housing, student activities,
health services, and dining will not prove enough.
Fortunately, Benton will not be dealing with
Ho rnewo od's academic programs, and the
Administration will have the chance to appoint a dean
concerned with more than just balancing a budget. As
dean, Benton has shown himself to be surprisingly
insensitive to the educational decline at Homewood, as
well as revealing a markedly pro-science bias. The new
dean must be willing to have a strong interest in the
entire spectrum of Homewood education.

The Walters Art Gallery is in
downtown Baltimore, right across
Monument Place from the Peabody
Conservatory. This one time private
collection is the largest in the South; it
ranks seventh nationally in the variety of
exhibits. Everything from Egyptian
mummies and Greek statues to suits of
armor and paintings by Ingres and
Delacroix adorn the gallery rooms.
25,000 objects repose in this gallery,
though only 20% can be exhibited at any
one time due to space limitations. With
the new wing now being built, these
limitations will be reduced This huge
collection was gathered over ninety years
by a father and son team of collectors,
William T. and Henry Walters. The
collection was begun in the 1840's.
During the Civil War period William
Walters lived in Paris, where he could
more easily pick up ancient and
contemporary art. Being an industrial
magnate, he looked for quantity as well
as quality, snatching up everything he
could. The contrast between the works of
greater and latter artists is readily
apparent and enhances the atmosphere,
serving as a laboratory for comparison,
and revealing those factors ever-present in
great art which are lacking in the
imitators.

Tale of a pawn broker
By BILL WITTING
Tick-tock. Tick-tock. The time clocks
race onward. Your heat's in your throat,
throbbing so hard you can barely think.
The ticking of the clock clogs your
consciousness. Hands shaking, you reach
forward—but no, that isn't the right
move. More seconds go by, you've got to
move. But where? His queen is sitting
there, just waiting to pounce in for the
checkmate—now you understand how
Bobby Fisher loses five pounds during a
chess game.
I wasn't the only one whose initiation
into the grim world of tournament chess
at Hopkins last week was a grueling one.
Four rounds in one day, considering the
pressure, would exhaust any pro; an
inexperienced amateur emerges a
grey-haired, feeble old man.
I was fortunate: in the first round, I
played someone who was even more
scared than I was. The rules said 40
moves for each player in an hour—that is
a move every minute and a half. My
opponent took off like the allowance was
a second and a half. Bang! He would slap
the button to start my clock running.
Tick-tock, tick-tock (the clocks tick very
loudly, intruding on your concentration.)
Bang! Bang! He just wouldn't slow down.
Nearing panic myself, I managed to hold
back, to look things over. Ten minutes
and sixteen moves later, I had it
wrapped—one down, three to go. We
played again just for fun: ten more
minutes and the poor guy decided to go
back to bed.
Trade Queens
Second round. Sweating. I was doing
great! Fifteen moves and I'd already

stolen a bishop and several pawns. What
to do next? All right, force him to trade
queens. I shoved my queen forward three
squares and let go. Oh no! He-can take it
with his bishop! I made a wild grab, but
it was too late. Wordlessly, the man
reached over and plucked my queen from
the board. There went round two.
As great as my disgust was, it could
not have matched the exhausted,
frustrated, exasperation which Phil Wong
must have felt when he lost his fourth
round contest for first place. Charlie
Young played superbly, bottling Wong up
so badly that he couldn't move even
when he had to. Tension mounted as
both began to worry about time trouble.
Other players, having completed their
games, gathered round to watch the
showdown.
Wong, the favorite, took the offensive,
fighting to free himself from the
entanglement. A pawn trade, and things
began to open up. He traded a knight for
a bishop and started to put pressure on
Young's queen. Then suddenly, there was
an audible gasp from the crowd as Young
slid his queen through a hole: Check! and
it was all over: Wong had to move the
king and Young stole his queen.
Obviously overwrought, Wong played
on for a few more moves, but the futility
finally overwhelmed him and he stopped
the clocks. With the outcome decided, all
tension subsided. After a few minutes
compiling statistics, everyone began to
disappear, eagerly hurrying home to seek
the solace of a warm, comforting bed and
a good night's sleep. And this was
supposed to be a vacation from studying!

By ROBERT PAULUS
The first national Conference
for a Critical Examination of the
Use and Abuse of Methadone will
be held at Antioch College's
Center for Social Research and
Action in Baltimore on May 13
and 14.
Although there have been
annual conferences dealing with
the advantages of methadone as a
detoxification agent and as a tool
for treatment of heroin
addiction, the Antioch
conference marks the first
attempt to critically examine
methadone maintainance as a
cure for drug addiction.
The two-day conference will
focus on the psychological,
political and radical as well as the
scientific implications of
widespread legal and illegal use of
methadone.
Participants
Participants in the lectures,
discussions and workshops will
include doctors, therapists, social
workers, counselors, researchers,
addicts, ex-addicts, drug abuse
administrators, clergy and other
interested citizens. Conference
coordinator and Center
Codirector Abram Eng!email
stated that the conference will
try to foster full participation
and leadership by those persons
who have been most deeply
affected by the use of

methadone.
A major function of the
Antioch conference will be to
examine the effectiveness of
methadone in narcotic
substitution therapy. Discussions
will center around the question
as to whether or not methadone
actually decreases the addict's
craving of other narcotics. In
addition, Dr. Blanfordy of the
Gerstalt Institute will present a
paper on the subject of
methadone as a "block" in
psychotherapy.
The second day of the
conference will concentrate on
alternatives to methadone
maintenance. Dr. Charles Rohrs
of Odyssey House will compare
methadone maintenance to
heroin maintenance. Medical
alternatives to methadone will be
discussed by Dr. Michael Smith
of Lincoln Hospital, New York.
The nonmedical side of the
methadone problem will also be
studied during the conference.
Legal implications of involuntary
methadone programs and the
political and economic aspects of
the methadone industry will be
examined.
Synthetic
Methadone is a synthetically
manufactured drug which has
been legally administered to
heroin addicts throughout the
country to fulfill the addicts'

medical need for other narcotics,
and to allow some addicts to
gradually "detoxify." While there
are some 35,000 "legal addicts"
on methadone maintenance in
the United States, the effects of

methadone have not been
thoroughly researched. As a
result, the Antioch Conference
was designed to provide further
information on the drug.

The Walters Art Gallery is in
downtown Baltimore, right across
Monument Place from the Peabody
Conservatory. This one time private
collection is the largest in the South; it

the new wing now being built, these
limitations will be reduced This huge
collection was gathered over ninety years
by a father and son team of collectors,
William T. and Henry Walters. The
collection was begun in the 1840's.
During the Civil War period William
Walters lived in Paris, where he could
more easily pick up ancient and
contemporary art. Being an industrial
magnate, he looked for quantity as well
as quality, snatching up everything he
could. The contrast between the works of
greater and latter artists is readily
apparent and enhances the atmosphere,
serving as a laboratory for comparison,
and revealing those factors ever-present in
great art which are lacking in the
imitators.

Tale of a pawn broker
By BILL WITTING
Tick-tock. Tick-tock. The time clocks
race onward. Your heat's in your throat,
throbbing so hard you can barely think.
The ticking of the clock clogs your
consciousness. Hands shaking, you reach
forward—but no, that isn't the right
move. More seconds go by, you've got to
move. But where? His queen is sitting
there, just waiting to pounce in for the
checkmate—now you understand how
Bobby Fisher loses five pounds during a
chess game.
I wasn't the only one whose initiation
into the grim world of tournament chess
at Hopkins last week was a grueling one.
Four rounds in one day, considering the
pressure, would exhaust any pro; an
inexperienced amateur emerges a
grey-haired, feeble old man.
I was fortunate: in the first round, I
played someone who was even more
scared than I was. The rules said 40
moves for each player in an hour—that is
a move every minute and a half. My
opponent took off like the allowance was
a second and a half. Bang! He would slap
the button to start my clock running.
Tick-tock, tick-tock (the clocks tick very
loudly, intruding on your concentration.)
Bang! Bang! He just wouldn't slow down.
Nearing panic myself, I managed to hold
back, to look things over. Ten minutes
and sixteen moves later, I had it
wrapped—one down, three to go. We
played again just for fun: ten more
minutes and the poor guy decided to go
back to bed.
Trade Queens
Second round. Sweating. I was doing
great! Fifteen moves and I'd already

stolen a bishop and several pawns. What
to do next? All right, force him to trade
queens. I shoved my queen forward three
squares and let go. Oh no! He-can take it
with his bishop! I made a wild grab, but
it was too late. Wordlessly, the man
reached over and plucked my queen from
the board. There went round two.
As great as my disgust was, it could
not have matched the exhausted,
frustrated, exasperation which Phil Wong
must have felt when he lost his fourth
round contest for first place. Charlie
Young played superbly, bottling Wong up
so badly that he couldn't move even
when he had to. Tension mounted as
both began to worry about time trouble.
Other players, having completed their
games, gathered round to watch the
showdown.
Wong, the favorite, took the offensive,
fighting to free himself from the
entanglement. A pawn trade, and things
began to open up. He traded a knight for
a bishop and started to put pressure on
Young's queen. Then suddenly, there was
an audible gasp from the crowd as Young
slid his queen through a hole: Check! and
it was all over: Wong had to move the
king and Young stole his queen.
Obviously overwrought, Wong played
on for a few more moves, but the futility
finally overwhelmed him and he stopped
the clocks. With the outcome decided, all
tension subsided. After a few minutes
compiling statistics, everyone began to
disappear, eagerly hurrying home to seek
the solace of a warm, comforting bed and
a good night's sleep. And this was
supposed to be a vacation from studying!

who have been most deeply
affected by the use of

methadone.

Antioch conference will be to
examine the effectiveness of
methadone in narcotic
substitution therapy. Discussions
will center around the question
as to whether or not methadone
actually decreases the addict's
craving of other narcotics. In
addition, Dr. Blanfordy of the

of Lincoln Hospital, New York.

political and economic aspects of
the methadone industry will be
examined.
Synthetic
Methadone is a synthetically
manufactured drug which has
been legally administered to
heroin addicts throughout the

and to allow some addicts to

By TOM COLEY
The high-flying Hopkins
swimmers captured the Middle
Atlantic Conference
championships for the second
straight year last weekend at the
Athletic Center with an amazing
503% points.
The Blue Jays built up an
insurmountable lead during the
Friday night finals and literally
swam away from the nine-team
field on Saturday. Elizabethtown
College had to settle for the
runner-up spot once again with
their 225 points. Franklin and
Marshall College finished third
with 183 points.
The Hopkins swimmers won
eleven of the meet's fourteen
events and set six new MAC
records in the process.
Blue Sea

Friday and Saturday night the
spectators were able to observe a
"sea of blue" as three or four of
the six finalists were Blue Jays.

were highlighted by Bill Milne's
two record-breaking victories.

in his best time of 1:55.1, which
established new school, pool, and
MAC records. Milne then came
back to win the 200-yard
individual medley and establish a
new MAC record in 2:00.7.
Mark Horning and Jay Fortner
also won their specialties on
Friday. Fortner captured the
200-yard backstroke, and
Horning set a new MAC record
with his winning time of 22.5 in
the 50-yard freestyle.

Nigrelli and Jim Finnerty right

a close victory in the 400-yard

Swarthmore quartet.
